p: Mutations that occur in PSEN1, PSEN2, and APP are most associated with early onset AD and affect the deposition of oligomeric β-amyloid peptides, which is the earliest known step in the disease pathology of AD [ 5, 19]. More specifically, PSEN1 and PSEN2 are part of the gamma secretase complex and are involved in the cleavage of APP [ 5, 19]. Incorrect cleavage of APP by the gamma secretase complex leads to the accumulation of toxic β-amyloid peptide [ 20]. Mutations found in PSEN1 occur in intron 4 causing mis-splicing and exclusion of all or part of exon 4 [ 16]. In addition to this mis-splicing example, other mutations in PSEN1 can lead to alterations in the expression of β-amyloid [ 21]. Specifically for PSEN2, a splice variant lacking exon 5 has been documented and is found in both early and late onset AD [ 22]. However, little is known about how this splice form contributes to disease pathology or progression.
